--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "swpalmer2001" <scott.palmer@2...> 
wrote:
>  I believe a lot of it.  I want to start writing unit tests for my
> code and in general improve my development practices.   So I 
downloaded
> JUnit, and read through some articles and examples.
> They are all too trivial.

For last 2 years of using JUnit for several big project I have not 
found "real code", that is not possible to unit test, except bad 
design.
I am saying there is very little to none of the code that is 
considered a well designed and hard to test with JUnit.
All my tests look very trivial too, but they together are the net 
that catches 99% of the bugs. Time spent for building it worth every 
second!

> course not always.   How do you unit test such beasts?

> 
> So far in all my attempts to get started at this I find that the 
test
> code itself becomes very complex - not as complex as my application,
> but enough that the time I would end up writing and debugging the
> test seems completely unreasonable.   I would love to have the
> finished tests, but I simply can't see how I could justify writing
> them, as it would more than double my design and coding development
> time.

I would be glad to have a look on your complex code. Learning unit 
test writing is definetly better for new code in small projects, but 
once mastered those skills can easily be appied to "complex" code. 
Can you challenge me with an example of buildable code, that is so 
hard to test?


> In the end I would almost end up with an "automated user", and of
> course that is a tad extreme and prone to it's own sorts of errors
> and assumptions.
Sounds like functional test.

> I've told co-workers about what I have read about unit testing,
> testing frameworks etc.  None of my co-workers do unit tests, and ll
> of them have the same attitude.  Unit testing is too
> complex/difficult to use when making real complete programs.
> 
> So I'm asking... Who else has been down this path?  How do I get 
past this point?   Am I making sense or have I just gotten something
> completely wrong? Or is this unit testing just a passing fad that is
> really nothing more than a bunch of hype?

I've been there, down this path! And now I am unit test advocate in 
my team. It is one of the easiest XP policy to explain to managers. 
More IT managers convinced that unit tests can significanly improve 
quality of software. JUnit is very lightweight framework for unit 
tests.
